er 25, 2013
												I had a lot of fun with this game. Its by Rockstar Vancourver Studio, so it has a GTA feel to it, but its kept PG13. You start out as a new kid in a rich prep school and you have to make friends early. There are several different cliques in the school from nerds, jocks, greasers, preps etc. Each clique has their own missions and quirks.This game is not as open as I like, but I still had a lot of fun. You can choose to attend class or play hookie and do the missions. If you go to class you get combat bonuses like better sling shots and stink bombs.

content:
er 29, 2013
Bully, the brutally funny debut title from Rockstar Vancouver, takes the Rockstar tradition of groundbreaking, innovative, original gameplay and humorous tongue-in-cheek storytelling to an entirely new setting: the schoolyard. As a troublesome schoolboy, you'll laugh and cringe as you stand up to bullies, get picked on by teachers, play pranks on malicious kids, win or lose the girl, and ultimately learn to navigate the obstacles of the fictitious reform school, Bullworth Academy.

er 17, 2013
												Bully is a great game. The PC version however is good but only if you buy it through steam. I was unfortunate to by my first copy through amazon. Its not amazon's fault the product didn't work right off the bat. So I go to rockstar.com and low and behold this game has little to no support. It has one patch and the patch from the site will not install correctly if you run from their website. I looked up some pc gameplay and all the vids I found where people playing it on steam. So I went ahead and waited for a sale and got the game on steam. The game works just fine now. On a different note this game is so much better with a controller than with mouse and keyboard. At least in my opinion. If you only played the Playstation 2 version when this first came out you will be a little suprised that they added a few classes. These classes only serve as to unlock new clothing they added for your character. Otherwise its the same game you loved when you got it on Playstation 2. Now unlike other rockstar titles this is way toned down. No sex, murder, or guns. But Bully has a ton of chaotic fun that will keep you entertained and liking the story untill the end.

content:
y 25, 2012
												Bully: Scholarship Edition feels and plays basically like a trimmed and a lot less violent version of GTA, taking place in a fictional school in New England.The story is pretty generic: You're new to the school and no one likes you. In order to gain respect you fight your way to the top, blah...You have to attend classes in order to unlock certain abilities, upgrades and outfits. You also play pranks on your schoolmates in order to gain reputation from the various fractions, do side events to earn some additional stuff and cash or find collectibles scattered all over the city.The playtime should be something between 15 and 20 hours, depending on how much of the optional stuff you do and how often you fail.Note that this is a console port with quite a few flaws. The keys are not re-bindable and the only options available are: Resolution, AA, VSync and Shadow quality. The game plays like crap with keyboard & mouse, so I highly recommend to play it with a XBox controller.

content:
er 18, 2013
												This game is a classic. One of Rockstar's Finest games. It is essentially a heavily story-driven sandbox game. You're Jimmy Hopkins, a 15 year old ne'er do well who was just dumped at a boarding school by his parents. This school is a living hell. And you thought your high school was bad. Jimmy is a good kid at heart, despite what the title of the game would lead you to believe. It's all a matter of choice. You could either bully kids, or try to help them out. Morality vs. convinience.Expect frequent Catcher in The Rye references, sly sexual humor and typical teenage cursing.

												Best game Rockstar ever put out...and I think that is saying a lot! Check this out, and you won't be sorry... particular with the extremely cheap sale price this week!(Dec. 17th 2013)

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2014
												The sun is rising, it's a beautiful day.The alarm clock goes "BEEP BEEP BEEP" and you trampoline yourself into a vertical spine position called standing."My goodness, today is the first day of school" you hastily expel from your innards.That's right Peter, today is the first day of school but not only that my friend. Today is the first day of school at a new school.Your mother and stepfather will soon drop you off with hatred in their hearts at Bullworth Academy.There you will fight your way to the top and have everyone shout your name when you pass them."Bully: Scholarship Edition" they will shout repeatedlyIt will be a wonderful journey and it begins now.Bully: Scholarship Edition or more commonly nicknamed "Jimmy" is the main character of this video game and he's not afraid of showing it right away. The story is about him. The cutscenes star him. This is quite the problem for me because he shaves his head. This is something I do as well, for that reason I have trouble distinguishing fiction from reality and got into trouble with the police. Luckily we live in an age of mystery and magic, you don't need to play as Jimmy anymore. You can use technology called hacking to hack the video game and change the model you play as. I opted first in playing as one the adults as I thought maybe the lady folk around campus would be into more experienced men but no. No model would change the attitude they had against me, this made me sad. Hacking doesn't work on the people in the real world either.Gameplay is "Beat the jocks at dodge ball, play pranks on the preppies, save the nerds, kiss the girl and ultimately navigate the social hierarchy in the worst school around. " and that pretty much catches it all using the umbrella method. Now, I've only played it for 55 minutes but what I experienced during that time was wonderful. I hit people, threw books at people, hit on people, talked to people(thumps up edition), talked to people(thumbsdown edition), bought soda and meeting some kind of creature called a prefect you can easily avoid by just jumping all the time.The gameplay mechanics is what you would expect from a Rockstar PC port, somewhat clunky but generally okay. The game also features all kinds of education based mini games like chemistry, english, math, geography etc. All these subjects and their mechanics are highly representative of the American education system. In conclusion, it’s a beautiful sandbox-style game with beautiful characters and beautiful gameplay.3/10

content:
er 6, 2013
												Bully is a wonderful free-roam, perhaps one of my favourite Rockstar games. The graphics are mediocre by this time, but it's nothing to scoff at either. While the game is buggy and has some issues with AI, it's not usually game-breaking and you'll be too busy beating people up to care.The character depth is great, especially due to the fact that no two characters in Bully are the same, they each have their own personalities and traits, and if you don't think so, just stop to listen to them and maybe you'll see what I mean.The music is suitable and, for the most part, sets the emotion of the scene adequately.Bully is a great game and well worth the price.(P.S. Rockstar, make sequel pls)

content:
ry 28, 2016
												In Bully you play as Jimmy Hopkins, 15 year old problem teen who right at the begginning of the game is being left at Bullworth Academy boarding school by his mother and new step father who are about to leave for their honeymoon.When Jimmy first arrives at Bullworth he quickly learns he's at the bottom of the foodchain in the school and sets out to literally beat up each Cliques leaders to earn their respect.The game controls and plays very similarly to GTA with some differences.Jimmy is expected by teachers and prefects which act as the "police" within the school  grounds to attend classes on weekdays and go to bed on curfew.Nothing stops you from skipping class or staying up late, but if you get caught it can mean detention.Each class has its own minigame which gets harder each time you pass, and in the post-game you unlock some new classes you couldn't do at the start of the year.Combat is very similar to that of GTAIV, but heavily improved upon. There are many moves and techniques Jimmy can learn such as sweeping under someones legs to knock them over or uppercuts.When using a grapple on another student Jimmy is able to "bully" them in various ways.Overall I'd say this is one of Rockstars best releases to date, and one of the few games released by them that I still fully enjoy.If you enjoy GTA you're pretty much guaranteed to enjoy this.

content:
1, 2013
												WARNING: VERY BAD CONTROL SCHEME!  There is partial controller support, meaning it supports controllers but has a lot of problems with them.  Xbox 360 controllers are not plug-and-play, but they work as long as you enable them within the in-game options menu.  The game's default keyboard controls are terrible, and while the game is best played with a controller, it sometimes requires you to use a more accurate aiming tool, like a mouse or tablet, to play the minigames... well, you could probably do the minigames with your joysticks, but it would be unnecessarily difficult.  The minigames are clearly designed for a mouse.That aside, Bully is a nice game for how old it is.  It has decent visuals (nothing special), similar to GTA3 with characters closer to the style of Fable (sort of, see screenshots), and it plays fairly well.  The story has a lot of hilarious moments and some good laughs for people who like absurd phrases.  There are some gross-out moments, as well, so the game may not be for the squeamish.  Immature, snot-nosed brats should love it, though!  ;DThe only gripe I have besides the controls is that the AI is absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The characters will just stand around doing the same behavior, even saying the same phrase, non-stop for the entire time you're near them.  I wish the devs would have given NPCs more believable behavior patterns.  That said, if you run through the levels very fast, you will not notice that issue.You can play a bunch of metagames which help progress the story, but there is not much replay value, because the game really isn't that open and offers very few distractions to keep you occupied.  There is very little challenge to the game, but that may be a good thing for some players.Overall, my opinion allows the game a 3/5.  Get it if it's cheap.

												Pros:Another excellent Rockstar sandbox game, worth the price. Give this a go if you like GTA. I also recommend it for those who like GTA games but often find the story missions too difficult. Bully's missions are a lot easier than those found in most GTA games. There's a lot to do outside of the main story too, with countless side-missions, minigames, secrets and unlockables to find. The game's soundtrack is awesome, by the way, composed by Shawn Lee. If you play this game for more than ten minutes the music will have already been stuck in your head.Cons:If you're playing this on Windows 10 you may encounter crashes a fair few times, there are steps that can be taken to minimise the frequency of these crashes. I took these steps but I couldn't eradicate the crashes completely, I may have missed something however. Also, the game is locked at 30 FPS if you're worried about that. It can be brought up to 60 FPS with some tinkering if you like, I didn't mind it all that much. Another issue I had was the audio, outside of cutscenes I thought the characters' voices were too quiet and they were overpowered by the music, even though I had the speech option at max.To sum up, Bully is a unique, funny game with a great story, a fantastic soundtrack, a ton of side missions, a lot of pranks to pull and a lot of characters to interact with. The few technical problems I mentioned are outweighed by this game's qualities.

Bully takes place in Bullsworth Acadamy, and is about a young boy, who has been dropped off at this boarding school because of his wreckless behaviour in the past.Along the way you'll meet crazy characters such as a hobo that teaches you kung-fu, nerds, jocks, and of course, the headmaster.It is and open world game, but the world isn't as big as Liberty City, Vice City or San Andreas. Lessons are fun mini-games, and detentions also have their own mini-games, like lawn mowing or snow shoveling.This game deserves a sequel, and with recent news of Bully getting trademarked, we may have a glimmer of hope for Bully 2.That or it's a moblie port.Rating: 9.5/10

content:
er 29, 2013
												Bully was a game back in 2006 released for the PS2 that basically offered the gameplay of Grand Theft Auto to minors without penalty.Bully is a game where you play as 15 year old Jimmy Hopkins as he attempts to survive his high school days after his mother and step father drop him off due to their honeymoon. While Jimmy attempts to fit in, he does various jobs for each of the cliques at the School to gain their favour. Whether its getting som D&D pages back for the Nerds, beating up the Jocks for the Preps, or roughing up the Preps for the Greasers, Jimmy does pretty much everything possible to just survive.Gameplay wise, this is a text-book R* sandbox game with its own unique touches. You can go to class where you play mini-games to unlock new abilities, start fights with the various cliques of the school, or just be a delinquent and destroy everything.Bully was one of the most unique R* games in it's gameplay feel. Sure it plays pretty close to the Renderware Grand Theft Auto games (GTA III, Vice City, San Andreas), it has its own unique feel with a pretty interesting plot, some great voice acting, and missions and activities that are fun to play. It's 14.99 and the game is pretty long, so you do get your money's worth.

content:
er 5, 2011
												Definitely one of Rockstar's more focused efforts in their long line of open games, Bully still succeeds in staying true to the formula with a somewhat, just a bit though, focused narrative and time constraints imposed on the player by the very nature of the game - attending school. Characters and story are memorable and clearly intended as exaggeration of high-school stereotypes, although many come as 1-shots for some reason. One can't help but praise out-of-nowhere dramatic final confrontation which ends up being EXTREMELY satisfying and just, though. Only really negative side I can think of is the fact that this isn't such a great port.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Bully on PS2 was one of my favourite games in the Rockstar catalogue back in the day, and so I was excited to get my hands on the Scholarship Edition which promised to bring the world of Bullworth Academy and its surrounding towns into glorious HD life. And whilst textures and draw distance have been improved, B:SE isn't without its issues. The game is noticeably buggy, more so than the original and especially prevalent with the AI behaviour, particularly as you have a whole school's worth of NPCs running about. The new classes/minigames feel tacked on and are of poor quality, with the bonuses you gain in completing them utterly pointless. And call me vain, but I also dislike main character Jimmy Hopkins' new face; I mean, the kid wasn't exactly going to win any male model prizes back in 2006, but his makeover makes it seem like you're now controlling a middle-school aged Wayne Rooney who, in case you don't know, *definitely* isn't a looker. If you need to, give him a quick Google Image Search, and shield your eyes. One of the appeals of the original was saving up enough pocket money to buy new clothing for Jimmy, constantly dressing him up in just enough school uniform mixed with casual items so as to not get busted by prefects for violating the dress code, and so I don't think this demand for superficial consistency is too much of an ask.Despite these complaints, I'd recommend B:SE for any newcomers who never had the chance to play it before. The game is full of charm and accompanied by a brilliant soundtrack, finding a great balance between Rockstar's GTA formula with just enough new ideas to make it seem like a fresh enough experience for both GTA fans as well as those who've begun to grow tired with that series. However if you've already played Bully before, there isn't enough here to live up to the nostalgia, and I'd recommend investing on the PSN version of the original instead. For all its muddy graphics and atrocious framerate, particularly when the outside-school environments open up, the game was perfectly balanced in its original incarnation, without the out of place classes and, certainly, with a much better designed main character.7/10.

content:
13, 2015
												I've loved this game ever since it originally came out on PS2. I remember one time I invited a few other people that never played it before to play it and they loved it too! The story is amazing, the graphics are beautiful but not hard on a CPU, and gameplay is, good, I say that because some of the controls are bad and well, sometimes things work in weird ways that seem glitchy compared to certain things in Grand Theft Auto III, which came out a while before this. But either way, here are my ratings for the game:Game itself: 9/10Concept: 10/10 just for originality,Story: 10/10, some offensive stuff but that's one reason it's awesome,Controls (for PC): 4/10, aim mode is Up Arrow and to look around you use the mouse, and to move you use the WASD keys, when do you have time in like a boss battle or something to press Up?Physics (among other things): 5/10, you drop an item, it falls straight down. You jump off something with the Skateboard Bucky gives you early on in the game, you lose a lot of speed and sometimes just comepletely stop. Worst of all when you throw someone onto a street curb in such a way, and this is often, they will have gravity to that spot, meaning, they will be able to stand at a full 45 degree angle and not have to balance or anything.Overall: 8/10, this would have to be my favorite game on PS2 besides Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas and that underrated game called Gun.Thanks for reading this long review!

content:
27, 2014
												Bully. It's GTA, but without blood and deadly weapons, and instead of playing as an adult man, you play as Jimmy Hopkins. A 15 year old kid who's aggressive and a fighter, but not truly malicious. He only gives people what they have coming to them.Bully takes place in Bullworth, a town in New England. Your mom, well, Jimmy's mom, drops you off at Bullworth Academy. A boarding school. The school is full of bullies and corrupt teachers and it's up to you to put a stop to it.The game's storyline will guide you through six chapters (There are 65 missions, the sixth chapter is an endless free-roam chapter, giving you the chance to complete non-storyline missions and to collect collectables.) Each of them takes place in a different weather season. The missions vary, it's never the same. One time you're cleaning a rat infested library and the next time you're helping a teacher escape from a psychiatric hospital. As Jimmy, your main goal is to bring peace to the school by helping and befriending the five school cliques: The Nerds, the Jocks, the Bullies and the Preppies.Of course you'll have to go to class. These classes are: English, gym, geography, math (ew), music, shop, art, photography and biology. They are simple mini-games which become noticeably harder every time you attend them and make progress. You'll also have to deal with a time schedule. You can skip class, but you won't get any rewards if you do so and prefects will catch you if they see you outside of class. Jimmy, your character, is highly customizable. You can buy clothes, change your hairstyle and more. You can even buy a bike, a go-kart or a scooter if you saved up enough cash. Money can be earned by either taking a paper route, doing missions for townies or students or by completing storyline missions. You've got weapons. No, they are not guns and no you can't kill people. There's a super slingshot, you can use firecrackers, stink bombs, eggs, a bag of marbles, a bottle rocket launcher and so much more. You can also pick up one of the many objects around you (umbrella's, vases, bottles) and use them as a weapon.Interacting with your fellow students is fun too. You can talk to them, give them presents, put them in trash bins, punch them in the face (aka bully them) and even kiss them. (This only applies to several girls and yes, you can kiss some guys too if you're into that.)The game has a very impressive map size. You can explore the entire school, the school grounds, the town, a fully functional theme park, an industrial park and a few more awesome places. There are many collectables scattered around the map too.Bully may be pretty good, but it's not perfect. The graphics are rather outdated, the sound isn't that amazing and you will have to deal with odd controls and some bugs. But don't worry! It doesn't kill the fun. Bully is an amazing game and there's much to do. And for only $14.99 - £9.99 - €9.99, it's certainly worth it. Go buy it! I recommend you it!

content:
er 18, 2014
												Absolutely fantastic game. 2nd favorite Rockstar game, only behind Red Dead. (BTW, LORD GABEN BETTER PUT IT ON STEAM.) Bully revolves around the daily academy life of Jimmy Hopkins, a fifteen year old troublemaker and an all-around badass.The game is really cool because it's open world on the campus of Bullworth Academy. Now, this can be great for the 2 kinds of game players that exist. The ones that actually play a storyline and are afraid to be a ♥♥♥♥ in a videogame (Me), or someone who doesn't give a damn and just screws around hitting girls and giving prefects the wedgie of their life (Also Me).Pros:+Humor. LOTS of humor+Likeable Hero+Classroom Aspect+Voice acting (GOLD)+Not restricted to just the campus+Nonrepetetive storyline+Intresting story about betrayal and, well, BULLIES!+Antagonist is a ♥♥♥♥. (I like that)+YOU choose the way you play. Lover or Hater kind of thing+Unlockables+Character Customization+Interesting soundtrack+Fun Gameplay+Easy Achievements, sorta, on console+A Pretty lengthy storyline+Crime and punishment system is realistic-ish and is reasonable+Lenient Prefect escape systemCons:-Vague respect system-Graphics are a little painful to look at, but for it's time it's alright-Controls are something special-No AchievementsThe game is very good, and I give it an 89/100. This is also the first game I got all achievements on (LONG weekend).An underrated game that you should buy.Have fun hiding in trashcans, shoving Algie into a locker, beating up Tad, and making out with Mandy (or Eunice... if you're into that).

content:
15, 2014
												9/10Another great game by Rockstar!Short summary: A child/ younger persons GTA. No explicit language only minor ( B word for female dog is the strongest language used). Guns are replaced with school like weapons (eg Slingshot). Bikes and skateboards instead of cars.Has a good story and enjoyable gameplay. I quite like the idea that you are a bully to bullies rather than just a bully at a school. I thought the characters were rich with interesting personalites. The gameplay is very fun and even the school subject quests are entertaining (except for english, I found that one a bit boring). The side quests for NPCs are great fun, though there were times when I really wanted to punch the quest giver (which I eventually did). Even at a school there is a wide range of fun weapons to play with and a reasonable sized open world to explore.Overall I found this game throughrally enjoyable. I loved the story and I thought that the gameplay was excellent. I would reccommend that Rockstar fans should definatly buy it. If you have never played one of their games (GTA series, Red Dead Redemption etc.) I reccommend giving this game a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2015
												One of the best comedic open world games ever made that makes you feel like your in high school all over again.PROS-Fully Open World to Explore-Tons of Mini Games-Unique Leveling System Involving Schoolwork-Replay ValueCONS-30fps Lock (Mod Needed)STORYYou play as a young man who starts out being dropped off at a new school by his newlywed mother & stepfather as they go off on their honeymoon.  The story starts off great as you get to see the characters develop nearly right away.  The young boy is angry as hell & the mother don't give no ifs ands or buts about it as she's just married some rich guy.  Anyways, after all that you go to your new school & board room.  You then get the chance to learn your new natural habitat, meet some new friends, kick some nerd or jock butts.  All the fun stuff you'd do in a normal school :P.  As you progress you meet some new friends.  One's a sociopath while the other a more timid type of kid.  These are the two main characters that will help progress most of the story.  The end result is you becoming the unofficial king of the school & eventually the entire town where everyone knows you & respects you in some way.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is very similar to GTA type games.  You run around, can steal bikes or pick fights.  If you pick fights with adults you're gonna end up getting caught.  Adults are a lot harder to fight but can be managed if you have the skill or weapons at your disposal.  Cops are a lot harder, though.  If you get caught outside of school during early hours you will be sent to class.  Classrooms act as minigames that usually involve some sort of QTE segments but doing these are very benificial as you unlock upgrades, weapons & such from doing them.  If you finish all your schoolwork you can then explore the town freely without the fear of being arrested & sent back to class since you no longer have any classes that you're required to attend.  There are also a variety of minigames that are also fun & give ample rewards.  Arcade cabinets with high scores that are actually fairly easy are one of the required mini games to progress the main story, but you do get a new weapon from doing it as well.  Then there are bike races which are really fun & give you new bikes to choose from as well as an entire theme park with it's own set of mini games & prizes such as a motor scooter which is the best vehicle in the game.  If you're riding the scooter without a helmet cops will give chase.  There are also odd jobs you can get around the town like delivering papers or mowing lawns.  Paper delivery plays like the best version of Paper Boy you've ever played & mowing lawns plays just as you'd think it would.  Just don't mow the flowers.  There's also a punch out like boxing mini game that ends up unlocking new fighting moves to utilize in combat.All in all everything about the gameplay is well done with very little glitches or hang ups on controls.  I never had a problem doing anything in particular myself.  Exploring the world is one of the many pleasures in this game & there are lots of things to find such as trading cards, rubber bands, or gnomes to destroy.  OVERALLOverall, this game is worth every penny you spend.  It's got everything you'd want in a video game.  Open world to explore, solid progression system, mini-games, vehicles, etc.  It's all great & good fun.  If it's on a sale you should definitely pick it up.  Even if not on a sale it's worth every penny spent.  IMO this game is better than most of (if not all) the GTA games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
												I wouldn't buy this game. The interface is terribly clunky, and while I understand that this is supposed to be a "bad" school and kids are noisy, I have never once been in a place where there are two hundred people shouting the same six lines at the top of their lungs at all times. The sheer amount of loud, grating, poorly voiced "children" in this game is a marvel of auditory annoyance.In addition, the game makes a big deal about the choices you can make in dealing with the other students, however the pre-scripted events have no options whatsoever. Someone hits you with a slingshot and you have no option but to chase them down and beat them up, instead of having an option to simply wait and get revenge later, or ignore it entirely (with whatever penalties are appropriate).The graphics range from not impressive to abysmal and I don't know how Rockstar managed to screw up the controls and user interface so badly. Bully is probably the worst console port I've played in a very long time and about the only redeeming value to this game is it is a bit of gaming history, as a shining example of people freaking out about a "violent video game" that's incredibly bad.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2013
												As Rockstar's only T rated game, it's also one of their most unique for the setting, mini "class" games, advancement through society and character development. Obviously, the game is about bullying and fighting your way through the ranks only to try and bring peace to the school. While the plot may not be as strong as other Rockstar titles, it's certainly more fun than others for the exploration of the school and outside areas, including the town, carnival, and industrial park. Overall, it's an exceptional game.You are Jimmy Hopkins, all around average teen that is sent to a private school in the New England area. Jimmy eventually befriends the idealist Gary Smith, and Pete Kowalski, the resident dweeb. Jimmy is able to attend classes, make friends, have a relationship, and fight bullies. The main enemies are the preps and jocks, but there's an underlying story here as the game takes place throughout the school year.I have to say, watching Bully's story unfold was exciting and exhilerating as I was fondly reminded of Harry Potter.9.0/10

content:
ry 7, 2015
												was running from a prefect and he got stuck in a wall420/360 would get stuck againEDIT: Holy nutballs I based a review off a rare glitch? Damn must have I been high, erm.Bully:Scholarship Edition is a third person game that takes place in a VERY stereotypical american high-school, if you're looking to do a Columbine this isn't for you unless you want to substitute with a slingshot or spud gun.In one mission you break into the girls dorm and steal panties.The game is full of fun minigames, hell some of the classes are minigames in themselves. (I don't count Maths and English as minigames, ok.)You can basically do whatever you want in a school-themed game and not have any real life consequences, go ahead and shoot that fat nerd with the spud gun.You've got the Nerds, the Preppies, the Greasers and i'm pretty sure everyone would know there would be Jocks in this kind of game, each with their own theme whenever you're fighting someone a part of their faction, speaking of themes, when you get the game you get the soundtrack too for free, some of the soundtrack (like the theme that plays when a prefect chases you down) sounds like 80s cop music and it's just so memorable it's no surprise that it may get stuck in your head quickly.Let's just get to the most fun parts, you can beat people up of course, you could throw itching powder at people and watch them thoughtlessly scratch themselves, you can throw stinkbombs and firecrackers, shoot a slingshot, bottle rocket launcher (kinda like fireworks), and spud gun, make out with several different girls (Or guys, don't talk about that seriously.).The game offers at least 15 hours of gameplay unless you just speedrun it and have no fun at all outside of the main storyline.Conclusion: 8.5/10, I absolutely wish for a sequel, and a sequel with many more hours of gameplay, Happy nerd hunting, gamers!

I've played this on Windows 7 and 8, and I was actually able to complete the full story without any crashes. It's a heavy game however. If you want max settings PLUS a solid framerate, you're definitely going to need pretty high specs. I'm using GTX 960 and I'm getting 60 FPS on max settings. Mind you there is a released executable which replaces the original one, removing the 30 FPS limit. I'd only recommend getting that if you have 8 or more GB of ram. Other than that, it's a really juicy story, lots of fun, and can easily be modded. 10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 16
												OK, so here's my take on the crashing thing:THIS GAME CRASHES. A LOT. It crashes roughly on-par with any Bethesda game with mods or memory issues, which is maybe twice every couple of hours. I played a full hour before I even found my first crash.I've seen A LOT of people giving a variety of stories on their own experiences with the crashes. Some saying extreme things, like the game doesn't even run in the first place, or that they can place only about 10 minutes before it crashes. I haven't experienced this.My first experience with the crash was by the mission "Save Algie", which is maybe the 4th or 5th mission in the game. I figured, "Oh, there it is-- the mythical crashes!" No problem, I thought, I'll just load a save..Oh..Oh... I forgot to save since the beginning of the game.SO BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK-- Be aware that Steam will refund the game if you decide you don't want it within 2 hours of gameplay; I would DEFINITELY recommend this game, crashes and all, if it were less than 10$, so definitely get it if it's on saleThe game itself is amazing; I've played it on every console I've ever owned, I've played it since I was a small child, I can even associate many of the events of my early life to playing the game. I even went back on the day I graduated high school to play the game with my friends. It's an instant classic and is tons of good fun, so this game would be golden if not for it's technical issues.All of this said, I *can* recommend the game with a bit of an asterisk next to it: SAVE OFTEN. Do a mission, and return to the dorms to save. I, myself, can have plenty of fun with this game so long as I remember to save after every event, which is not too hard as there's various places to save in the game. That said, if you do buy the game and find you crash too frequently to return and save your game, then feel free to refund it.TO SUMMARIZE: The game *does* crash, but I think it's a managable issue that makes this game worth it depending on your definition of "worth it"-- i recommend potential buyers buy the game, see what severity they have of the issues, and decide for themselves if they want a refund.Oh, and of course, this isn't to say that Rockstar or /anyone/ shouldn't patch the game-- Come on. If Steam is gonna pull 15$ in on this game, then they need to make sure it isn't working worse than their FREE games. It's not that dated-- I can play Wolfenstein 3D with minimal issues on Steam but can't make a PS2-era game work. Bull.

content:
4, 2014
												While this PC port comes with awful controls, you can customize them, or do what I do and use a 360 controller.I'll start this review by saying Bully is one of my favorite games of all time, I had it on the Playstation 2, and I kept my PS2 for 2 years until I discovered this was on steam, where I bought this and donated my PS2. Bully has what I consider a great storyline, plenty of weapons and perks, great AI, good replayablility (I've beaten the story, so I loaded a save file and have just been free roaming this whole time. You can unlock a moped, and eventually a go-kart along with a bunch of different weapons from bags of marbles to potato guns. When you first arrive at the school, you are hated for being the dumb new kid. As the game goes on, you gain respect for doing multiple missions, which is how you are treated. I'd say this game is worth $15 but during sales its gone down to $3 or $7. This is a must have in my opinion, after you complete the first chapter you get to go into the local town and cause mayhem, and with a developer such as rockstar you really can't go wrong.The modding community is not what is could(should) be, I was able to download a mod to put the super spudgun into the game but I've only found a few others (One that added cars, different outfits, etc) OverallI'd give this a 10/10.

ry 6, 2014
												This is certainly one of the best games Rockstar has ever made. Why? Because it's incredibly unique. You play Jimmy, a (possibly 90's?) schoolkid which was sent to Bullworth, at which he spends most of his time. He's a Bully, but a good guy at heart.The game continuesly opens up and gives you more and more tools to play around with, while the Story is pretty appealing since there's a bunch of change and you won't often see the same mission twice.Though, there is one negative point: The PC Port and KB/M controls are absolutely terrible. If you're going to buy this, make sure you have a controller, otherwise it's not bearable. Don't worry about not being able to aim properly, since you won't shoot too often either way, and when you have to, it isn't hard.

4, 2014
												While this PC port comes with awful controls, you can customize them, or do what I do and use a 360 controller.I'll start this review by saying Bully is one of my favorite games of all time, I had it on the Playstation 2, and I kept my PS2 for 2 years until I discovered this was on steam, where I bought this and donated my PS2. Bully has what I consider a great storyline, plenty of weapons and perks, great AI, good replayablility (I've beaten the story, so I loaded a save file and have just been free roaming this whole time. You can unlock a moped, and eventually a go-kart along with a bunch of different weapons from bags of marbles to potato guns. When you first arrive at the school, you are hated for being the dumb new kid. As the game goes on, you gain respect for doing multiple missions, which is how you are treated. I'd say this game is worth $15 but during sales its gone down to $3 or $7. This is a must have in my opinion, after you complete the first chapter you get to go into the local town and cause mayhem, and with a developer such as rockstar you really can't go wrong.The modding community is not what is could(should) be, I was able to download a mod to put the super spudgun into the game but I've only found a few others (One that added cars, different outfits, etc) OverallI'd give this a 10/10.

er 30, 2013
												In this game you play as 15 year old Delinquent Jimmy Hopkins as he goes through life in his new boarding school, bullworth. Bullworth has 4 types of students. The Greasers, leather jacket wearing punks who try to act tough, The Nerds, weak mischievous fools who usually use stink bombs on bullies, The Preps, High life living chaps who only associate with other wealthy students and they also love the sport of boxing, and finally the Jocks, they rule the school and everyone knows it. In this game you can beat up practically anything from guys to girls to rats. You can go into town and visit different shops like the barber shop. You can go on panty raids. You can vandalize walls. You can prank people. You can do every bad thing you could have done in school.

												*For me, this is the BEST Rockstar Game ever. This game has got Great story about being a guy who was in a school with FULL of Bullies.*Gameplay is so exciting. But if you're playing with Controller. Because this game is a Port. *There are different activities in this game. You can race with bike, you can race with Go-Kart you can bully nerds, you can play in carnival, you can kiss girls or you can be pervert, or you can be a student (like attending a lesson) *Lessons are exciting. But if you want to pass Geography and English, open the internet before starting. Because they are VERY challenging.*Characters are great. Voice actors did great performance.*Graphics are good if you're playing in High options. But they're good all the time. *Musics are AWESOME. If you want to listen all of the songs after completing the game, they're located in games program files.Story: 10/10Gameplay: 10/10 (with controller)Music: 10/10Final Verdic: 10/10

content:
er 13, 2015
												My option and review... Well first of all i just bit scracthed game (33hours, and on start still)This game has multiplayer on developement and also otherwise good roleplay game as offline mode already..My options are simple since i have played this on PS2 as i were really young kid.But lets start..First of all game gives you nice options and items etc... as thinking its old already.On start of game on its very hard specially without controller but will be easy after hour.Some missions might be hard like "Save the Algie / Help the Algie"Game actually really teaches English words, Math, Mouse control (Biology), Music, Chemistry (Focusing skills)Game gives you nice tools and stuff to explore and find out.Game has semi-big map for so old game.. But its not open on start yet.Game works nicely on Windows 10 after chancing some settings and i will be glad to help with them. (Not perfectly still)I love the game as it.. Its story about "Jimmy" who helps bullies or defence's nerds.. very simple by doing missions.If you like games like Grand Theft Auto then you will love this... YOU DONT HAVE VEHICLES ON START.But in fact.. Looking how old game is and how huge userbase it has.. It even gives you alot Steam Guide contet and mods at internet. So if you are looking for game to waist +100hours at least.. Then get Bully! I can tell you its worth of money even for 30hours speedrush..But if your gamer like me who likes to do mini-missions, run around maps and explore etc.. You will easily spend up to 300hours to this game. ! :)

Also the PC controls are really funky its strange but anyways this game is amazing love the gameplay and story it wont make you bored at all!Bully: Scholarship Edition takes place at the fictional New England boarding school, Bullworth Academy and tells the story of mischievous 15-year-old Jimmy Hopkins as he goes through the hilarity and awkwardness of adolescence.8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2014
												Jimmy Hopkins, a young delinquent teen, gets sent to the notoriously bigoted Bullworth Academy by his mother, who's caught up in another fling with an older man. He learns his way around the school and makes friends and enemies (well, pretty much just enemies). Taking down clique after clique, he clashes with Gary, a teenage sociopath, for the title of the ruler of the school.I liked this game! The story was amusing and there were several interesting characters. However, the voice acting was painful and the graphics weren't the best Rockstar could have done. The music was GREAT and there was an intricate web of characters and quests to mess around with if the main story got a bit boring. The fighting was a bit strange at first, with unnatural keyboard positions forcing me to twist my hands around each other, but you get used to it, and by the end of the game you're a champ.Basically GTA for teenagers.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												I've had tremendous difficulies trying to get this game to run properly. As things currently stand, there really is no option that would yield in excess of 45minutes of gameplay on Win10.  No matter what you do with the compatibility settings, no matter what you do wih CPU core affinity setting - nothing manages to mend the utter mess that this game is on a Win10 platform. I've tried two different hardware configs, quad core i5 with a discrete AMD GPU and a dual core i3 with Intel HD5500 graphics chip. Both suffer from the same kind of crashes occuring in seemingly reliable intervals.My advice would be to definitely wait for a sale ( I bought it for measly $3 ) and also to not be afraid of relying on Steam's refund policy in case you find out that the game runs poorly on your system as well.

content:
er 1, 2013
												Bully is a fantastic game, which exhibits Rockstar's mastery of the GTA style open world gameplay. Bully is charming as hell, and has Rockstar's trademark top notch video game writing. If you cant get your hands on the PS2 version of the game, this is an acceptable purchase, although I recommend getting it on a big sale. The PC port's quality however is somewhat questionable; mainly in the sound department. The sound is so loud I have to turn down the volume on my computer and the game almost all the way for it to be comfortable to listen to. Not only that, but the game's age means the repeated use of banter and sound cues, so imagine listening to 10 different characters inside the school saying satirically stupid things you've already heard 10 times, at ear piercing volume. Otherwise, this port is pretty decent, and worth your money if you cant get your hands on a cheap PS2 copy.

												This game is a classic. I found using the mouse to be too hard and the controls were awkward. I used a wired xbox 360 controller that had to be connected before the game was opened for it to recognize, the controller made a huge difference. Being timed constantly could annoy some, for me it made the game more realistic (if you don't go to bed before 2 am you pass out). The soundtrack was great, so was the dialogue and game play. I had no trouble running this on Windows 7. Bully is not about being a bully, it is more about stopping clicks and bullying at the prep school. This game is a hidden gem and a tonne of fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6, 2014
												Pros:1. You won't get bored with this game's storyline. It's funny and interesting all the way through.2. Separate school "factions," i.e. nerds, bullies, jocks, etc. Doing certain events in the game raise/lower respect with different groups. You can also access different groups' hideouts.3. Lots of fun to be had outside of the events. Causing mayhem in the school is entertaining enough.Cons:1. I found the controls a little awkward, especially when fighting other characters.2. This might have been my experience, but it takes a while to load different areas. This really effected the flow of the game.3. It takes a bit of learning to coordinate through the characters' schedule. Getting caught outside of class while in the middle of an event can cause a reset, which can be irritating if you're in the middle of a particularly difficult event.I'm sort of neutral on whether to recommend this game or not. I really enjoyed the storyline, the characters, and the extra details added to the game (such as the different seasons). However, I found myself becoming disinterested quickly between the long loading screens and sometimes difficult to achieve events. But if these things don't bother you, I would say you should get it.

content:
r 11, 2013
												Two quick things to note before you purchase Bully: Scholarship Edition: 1. The game runs at 30fps natively (Whoop de doo, but apparently this is an issue for some people.)2.  An XBox 360 pad or 360 pad emulating software is highly recommended to play this game properly. Other configurations can work, but it works best with 360-styled controls.Anyway...Bully: Scholarship Edition is a 2008 upgrade of the 2006 PS2 game, so don't expect a lot of the bells and whistles that open world games of today have, and even in scale it's much smaller than Rockstar's other PS2 offerings. The smaller scale works in Bully's favor however, as the world is much easier to navigate and able to breathe a bit more. In the game you'll spend your time juggling your school studies alongside completing various missions to advance the story and curry favor with the various cliques around campus. Mission structures are fairly simple and easy to execute and have a certain charm to them given the high school setting. Blowing up toilets with firecrackers, dropping stink bombs in lockers, and rolling teachers down a hill an a locked porta potty are a lot more charming than the typical Rockstar fare of "Go here, shoot dudes, now go here." There's still a bit of open-world repetition to the process, but the story missions are varied enough and the scholastic mini-games fun enough that tedium rarely sets in. Narratively, Bully is more a comedy than most open-world games. There are quite a few genuine laugh oud loud lines and moments that make seeing the story through a worthwhile endeavor. Though the story and characters are brilliantly acted, they're unfortunately not written quite as well as they should be and the overall narrative and anti-bullying messages end up muddled. The main antagonist only appears in the opening and final chapters and the climax feels very slapdash and out of nowhere. With as strong as the Grand Theft Auto PS2 games were in this department, it's a bit of a bummer that Bully ended up getting a bit of a short stick. All that said, if you missed Bully the first time around, it's certainly worth a look. There's enough charm, comedy, fun things to get into, and great acting to keep the tedium of an overworld game from creeping up too often, just be aware that the payoff might not be exactly what you were hoping for.

content:
29, 2014
												This was a fantastic game back in the day of the PS2 era, still is to be honest. It's great when Rock star bring their games to pc, *Cough* Red Dead Redemption *Cough*.So with Bully being developed by beloved RockStar, it was designed from the same vein as GTA...but with kids...and no guns...or killing. Not necessary a major drag, you just get to run around with a super powered slingshot, stink bombs and fire crackers to really annoy people.The game is based around a 15 year kid called Jimmy Hopkins, who is transferred to a boarding school because his mum wanted to go on a 12+ month holiday. Lucky her, eh? So you're the new kid, and you need to work your way up the ranks to be at the top of the school. So naturally no one respects or fears you to start with, even the nerds of the school. So you do the usual mission progression and go through the chapters, which are pretty much like school terms, and you work for different school groups to gain their respect and trust.That's pretty much the jist of the game, other than that it's got you're typical collectables hunt, garage full of vehicles (in this case it's push bikes), shops selling you goods to help you with your carnage, and mini games to help you earn extra cash / abilities.The mini games are kinda fun and can completed fairly quickly. You've got your class room mini games and your 'earn some do$h' mini games. The cash ones are typical teenager jobs, such as a paper route or mowing lawns. But with the class room mini games they help improve Jimmy's abilities, such as chemistry lessons help buff up your chemistry set to create more useful and powerful prank tools. Auto shop gives you better push bikes, English helps you pick up the ladies ;D and so on. The class room mini games can essentially be completed in the first chapter, so no more lessons for the whole year! If only...*Sigh*Quite a lengthy game, if you go for 100% completion. The story is a bit meh and generic, like it's been done in a way before in previous RockStar game. Not going to give too many spoilers now! You'll just have to play and find out ;)  Then again, I could be completely getting one of the GTA games plots all wrong in my head, I hope not.But there are some good moments in the story with memorable, and stereo typical, characters you expect from a US school. Can't say I can really relate to be honest, British high school life is waaaaaaaay different. Thanks for butchering the spirit of The Inbetweeners, USA...An annoying factor to the game is the restriction at night where you can't be out of your dorm past 8 pm, other wise you get chased by the never sleeping prefects and police. If you're out after 2 or 3 am, you automatically get knocked out and appear in your dorm for 8 am. So you can't be a crazy kid and never sleep, ever.I do have to you warn you though, since this was a console port to the PC the controls aren't 100% perfect. So I recommend playing with a controller. Not the keyboard & Mouse!Over all the game isn't too bad, defiantly worth picking up if you have nostalgic feelings towards this game. I know I did, and didn't regret it! :DIn conclusion:  Fairly decent graphics from the PS2 era.  Good story, the game is quite lengthy if you also do the side content.  Excellent alternative to the GTA series, if you're looking for a less violent game.  Plenty of side content to keep a completionist busy for a few hours.  Fun character clothing customising. Make Jimmy look like a right ponce.  Fairly big open world.  Irritating in game hours, in which you have only so many to do stuff in.  Poor port to PC, use a game pad rather than a keyboard & mouse.7 / 10 Get the Go-Kart asap, other wise you won't be able to run the old ladies over fast enough before they dive out of the way.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
												Performance wise it did crash 2-3 times, but overall ran really smoothly for such an "old-ish" ps2 game, for me personally, it seemed a really alright port. The controls IMO were quite easy to get accustomed to if you edited them to your liking, played it with keyboard and mouse and persoanlly loved the experience.The world is filled with small interactions and stuff that'll make your stance between missions enjoyable and not make you feel like you are running around in circles in an open world made just for the sake of padding hours in it. It has a great variety of really chrming "weapons" that fit completly with the school setting. They managed to make classes incredibly fun, which it's a merit on it's own, from dissecting frogs to cranking a bike the enjoyment of them is quite great, although some do get a little bit tedious over time. Got almost all the classes completed in a single playthrough, but you'll miss a few unless you keep playing after endgame.Customization is alright, but if you change hairstyles you change jimmy's whole face quality/shading/structure which is kinda weird but passable considering the age of the game. Clothes are pretty varied and fun. Story and characters are cliché to a humorous extent, but it's what gives it al lot of the charm this game has. The dialogue is hilarious in most of the cases, mocking everything high school represents and every person you can find in one in a sometimes subtle and sometimes in your face humor that rarely fails to deliver chcukles. Even with all the hilarious, this game does not fail to deliver a great story that let's you taste progression in every part of it. The game did get incredibly easy midway through tho, but was still fun just over how much you can ♥♥♥♥ around the school, the city and the amusment park.Side activities pop up while riding your bike/skateboard/running around town and sometimes on the map if they are "story-ish" related, but the non story or "story-ish" ones get a little bit repetitive and you'll most likely end up not caring about them because you'll be bathing in money in no time even without doing them.Got 22 hours in it while doing all of the sidequests but 2, almost all the classes, and ♥♥♥♥ing around town very little, if you like collectibles and stuff it will take you quite a while more as there are 2 types of collectibles that are quite large in number. So you'll definetely get a bang for your buck with this game.Definitely my favorite rockstar game, couldn't recommend it enough!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 2, 2015
												I am so ecstatic that this game runs properly on my PC; I was incredibly intimidated by all of the Negative reviews claiming it's broken. Perhaps it's because my PC is an outdated laptop...Others have said it, so I'll be brief: From the developer, you already know that it's an open-world sandbox. Instead of a gangster/criminal/cowboy, you play as an outlaw/thug/ne'er-do-well in a preparatory school. The game is truly like The Warriors + GTA: 3/Vice City/SAndreas, in the mechanics; The game is truly unique otherwise.One of the things that impressed me most about Bully is how they were creative in rewarding players for going to class:Do well in English/Art (I forget which) to learn social skills (so much making-out with chicks).Do well in Chemistry to learn how to make Firecrackers and so forth.Do well in Gym to learn more advanced fighting techniques (or find scrap around the school and give it to the hobo that lives on the grounds, to learn "super-classified" fighting techniques).Etc., etc..P.S.: No Rockstar Social Club!EDIT: Huhhhhh, yet again, a port from an old-♥♥♥ game is (")shoddy("). TO BE SURE, with all of these ports - I am soooo glad to have them in my Library! Classics are classic. So any sort of complaining about the quality of the ports; I only do so to warn others (again, though, the majority (if not the enirety) of the Negative reviews are only Negative because "the game is broke,"). With Bully, the issues are: Sometimes while running, if you try and look around with the Right Stick, it is unresponsive or doesn't work as intended. Also, sometimes the picture tears and cutscenes get bogged down. These problems have not hampered me in any way, though.As for the game itself, I forgot just how unrelenting the Faculty is in combatting Truancy. Far too often, they will interrupt you while on a Mission because, with the way Time works, there is little breathing room. I'm pretty sure that when I played Bully originally, I just buckled down and went to all my Classes before attempting too many Missions. I enjoy this game, thoroughly; The persistent Prefects only add to the immersion.

												I remember putting this game into my PS2 way back when thinking it would just be Grand Theft Auto in a school. But boy was I happy that I was wrong. Everything about Bully, whether it be its characters, atmosphere, or even its soundtrack, just gives it way more personality than some Grand Theft Autos. It never feels like a chore to play, with more varied missions that keep it interesting long after you'd usually get bored with a GTA campaign. When I saw it on the Summer Sale, I got without hesitation and started my journey through Bullworth Academy for my 4th time. The only complaint I have with the game is that the towns outside of the school never feel as fleshed out or interesting. But that and minor glitches aside, Bully is a fenominal game. And if you have a controller nearby to use, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fenominal port.

content:
2, 2015
												I played this all the way through on the Xbox 360 Edition, Since I don't play consoles anymore, I picked this up for the PC when it was on sale.The game itself is really great, especially considering when it came out. The graphics have certainly aged, though they were good for their time. The gameplay itself is very unique, you get weapons which you'd expect a schoolyard deviant to have, like a slingshot, spud gun, etc. Plus, you have to perform minigames to do well in your classes. Despite your character's deviant nature, it actually will help you to advance in each class, giving you things like new ways to interact with people socially, new outfits, eventually new bikes, and in the science class, new, unique weapons.The Story is pretty long and you'll find yourself having a good, lengthy gameplay expirience, not to even begin with all the side-stuff and optional stuff you can do. But basically, as a new kid, you're trying to make as many allies as possible with all of the social groups at bullworth academy. I'm not going to say more because I don't want to spoil anything, but it's a good story nonetheless and one to be expected from a dysfunctional academy of sorts.At first the world feels a bit limited, but that's only as you're getting the ropes of things, once the town opens up, the world is actually a pretty good size, and like I said before, there is a fair amount to do, especially when the town opens up. There also is a curfew, if you're not back in your dorm by a certain time, you can get in trouble with the prefects or the police, and if you don't get back to school in time, you can even pass out and lose your shoes or some other items.While the game is good, the PC port is very lacking, I can't even get it to do 1080p right on one monitor without part of the picture disappearing and/or stretching out to the other monitor. There's also a pretty limited amount of graphics options, however, one thing to keep in mind too is that this game is several years old, and computers back then couldn't handle what the ones of today can.Overall, if you still after all these years haven't tried it, I would highly reccomend it, it's a great, full game that has a lot on offer and you will likely not be dissappointed. 8.5/10

content:
er 30, 2015
												NB: I've played more than the 0.2 hours shown because I had to download a patched .exe from the internet.It seems like a great game but I just can't recommend it on the PC. It's a poor console port with a 30fps lock and very few graphics options. The game will run fine, but it seems that on modern OSs it just isn't worth it. This game crashes constantly on modern systems with more than 2GB RAM (even the patched version).  The fact that there are no autosaves or checkpoints means that the game is pretty much unplayable, since every time you complete something the game crashes and all your progress is reset. Aside from that, the keyboard and mouse controls are absolutely abysmal, some of the worst I've seen on PC. If you are confident in buying this game, make sure you have a controller available. I read some reviews telling me to do this, and didn't heed them. Seriously, unless you have a controller you are absolutely wasting your time.In summary, a good game that's absolutely unplayable without a controller and incredibly restricted by bad porting and game instability.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2015
												Rockstar's known for going a little overboard on the comments from the random passers-by in their games, but this takes that to ridiculous levels. The comments are non-stop and take away any bit of pleasure I may have had with the game. "Stick it in your ear" is not something anyone should be forced to listen to every 20 seconds, I don't care what your crime is; well, that is, unless your crime is creating the game "Bully". I found myself trying to dodge pedestrians just to save my ears. My goal became to finish missions from the shadows with as little interaction with the game's population as possible.At that point, I found little to no pleasure in playing through the B-movie grade storyline with less than stellar voice acting. Sure, I could have turned the voice volume all the way down, but I would have lost out on the cut scenes too. I'm not saying that's anything to be missed, but, frankly, the game isn't challenging enough to make me want to play it without hearing the cut scenes as well. This review would have gone much better if the developers had added an option to decrease the amount of banter.UPDATE-------------Since I'm obviously in the minority with my negative review, I decided to take a look at the others. I noticed a lot of folks complaining of crashes on Windows 10. I'm playing the game on Windows 10 and was able to play it just fine. The game did crash once when I was attempting to set my resolution, but, outside of that, it ran like a champ. I would disregard the Windows 10 woes. If that was an actual issue, it seems to have been taken care of.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2014
												This was a fantastic game back in the day of the PS2 era, still is to be honest. It's great when Rock star bring their games to pc, *Cough* Red Dead Redemption *Cough*.So with Bully being developed by beloved RockStar, it was designed from the same vein as GTA...but with kids...and no guns...or killing. Not necessary a major drag, you just get to run around with a super powered slingshot, stink bombs and fire crackers to really annoy people.The game is based around a 15 year kid called Jimmy Hopkins, who is transferred to a boarding school because his mum wanted to go on a 12+ month holiday. Lucky her, eh? So you're the new kid, and you need to work your way up the ranks to be at the top of the school. So naturally no one respects or fears you to start with, even the nerds of the school. So you do the usual mission progression and go through the chapters, which are pretty much like school terms, and you work for different school groups to gain their respect and trust.That's pretty much the jist of the game, other than that it's got you're typical collectables hunt, garage full of vehicles (in this case it's push bikes), shops selling you goods to help you with your carnage, and mini games to help you earn extra cash / abilities.The mini games are kinda fun and can completed fairly quickly. You've got your class room mini games and your 'earn some do$h' mini games. The cash ones are typical teenager jobs, such as a paper route or mowing lawns. But with the class room mini games they help improve Jimmy's abilities, such as chemistry lessons help buff up your chemistry set to create more useful and powerful prank tools. Auto shop gives you better push bikes, English helps you pick up the ladies ;D and so on. The class room mini games can essentially be completed in the first chapter, so no more lessons for the whole year! If only...*Sigh*Quite a lengthy game, if you go for 100% completion. The story is a bit meh and generic, like it's been done in a way before in previous RockStar game. Not going to give too many spoilers now! You'll just have to play and find out ;)  Then again, I could be completely getting one of the GTA games plots all wrong in my head, I hope not.But there are some good moments in the story with memorable, and stereo typical, characters you expect from a US school. Can't say I can really relate to be honest, British high school life is waaaaaaaay different. Thanks for butchering the spirit of The Inbetweeners, USA...An annoying factor to the game is the restriction at night where you can't be out of your dorm past 8 pm, other wise you get chased by the never sleeping prefects and police. If you're out after 2 or 3 am, you automatically get knocked out and appear in your dorm for 8 am. So you can't be a crazy kid and never sleep, ever.I do have to you warn you though, since this was a console port to the PC the controls aren't 100% perfect. So I recommend playing with a controller. Not the keyboard & Mouse!Over all the game isn't too bad, defiantly worth picking up if you have nostalgic feelings towards this game. I know I did, and didn't regret it! :DIn conclusion:  Fairly decent graphics from the PS2 era.  Good story, the game is quite lengthy if you also do the side content.  Excellent alternative to the GTA series, if you're looking for a less violent game.  Plenty of side content to keep a completionist busy for a few hours.  Fun character clothing customising. Make Jimmy look like a right ponce.  Fairly big open world.  Irritating in game hours, in which you have only so many to do stuff in.  Poor port to PC, use a game pad rather than a keyboard & mouse.7 / 10 Get the Go-Kart asap, other wise you won't be able to run the old ladies over fast enough before they dive out of the way.

content:
4, 2015
												Performance wise it did crash 2-3 times, but overall ran really smoothly for such an "old-ish" ps2 game, for me personally, it seemed a really alright port. The controls IMO were quite easy to get accustomed to if you edited them to your liking, played it with keyboard and mouse and persoanlly loved the experience.The world is filled with small interactions and stuff that'll make your stance between missions enjoyable and not make you feel like you are running around in circles in an open world made just for the sake of padding hours in it. It has a great variety of really chrming "weapons" that fit completly with the school setting. They managed to make classes incredibly fun, which it's a merit on it's own, from dissecting frogs to cranking a bike the enjoyment of them is quite great, although some do get a little bit tedious over time. Got almost all the classes completed in a single playthrough, but you'll miss a few unless you keep playing after endgame.Customization is alright, but if you change hairstyles you change jimmy's whole face quality/shading/structure which is kinda weird but passable considering the age of the game. Clothes are pretty varied and fun. Story and characters are cliché to a humorous extent, but it's what gives it al lot of the charm this game has. The dialogue is hilarious in most of the cases, mocking everything high school represents and every person you can find in one in a sometimes subtle and sometimes in your face humor that rarely fails to deliver chcukles. Even with all the hilarious, this game does not fail to deliver a great story that let's you taste progression in every part of it. The game did get incredibly easy midway through tho, but was still fun just over how much you can ♥♥♥♥ around the school, the city and the amusment park.Side activities pop up while riding your bike/skateboard/running around town and sometimes on the map if they are "story-ish" related, but the non story or "story-ish" ones get a little bit repetitive and you'll most likely end up not caring about them because you'll be bathing in money in no time even without doing them.Got 22 hours in it while doing all of the sidequests but 2, almost all the classes, and ♥♥♥♥ing around town very little, if you like collectibles and stuff it will take you quite a while more as there are 2 types of collectibles that are quite large in number. So you'll definetely get a bang for your buck with this game.Definitely my favorite rockstar game, couldn't recommend it enough!

content:
y 2, 2015
												I am so ecstatic that this game runs properly on my PC; I was incredibly intimidated by all of the Negative reviews claiming it's broken. Perhaps it's because my PC is an outdated laptop...Others have said it, so I'll be brief: From the developer, you already know that it's an open-world sandbox. Instead of a gangster/criminal/cowboy, you play as an outlaw/thug/ne'er-do-well in a preparatory school. The game is truly like The Warriors + GTA: 3/Vice City/SAndreas, in the mechanics; The game is truly unique otherwise.One of the things that impressed me most about Bully is how they were creative in rewarding players for going to class:Do well in English/Art (I forget which) to learn social skills (so much making-out with chicks).Do well in Chemistry to learn how to make Firecrackers and so forth.Do well in Gym to learn more advanced fighting techniques (or find scrap around the school and give it to the hobo that lives on the grounds, to learn "super-classified" fighting techniques).Etc., etc..P.S.: No Rockstar Social Club!EDIT: Huhhhhh, yet again, a port from an old-♥♥♥ game is (")shoddy("). TO BE SURE, with all of these ports - I am soooo glad to have them in my Library! Classics are classic. So any sort of complaining about the quality of the ports; I only do so to warn others (again, though, the majority (if not the enirety) of the Negative reviews are only Negative because "the game is broke,"). With Bully, the issues are: Sometimes while running, if you try and look around with the Right Stick, it is unresponsive or doesn't work as intended. Also, sometimes the picture tears and cutscenes get bogged down. These problems have not hampered me in any way, though.As for the game itself, I forgot just how unrelenting the Faculty is in combatting Truancy. Far too often, they will interrupt you while on a Mission because, with the way Time works, there is little breathing room. I'm pretty sure that when I played Bully originally, I just buckled down and went to all my Classes before attempting too many Missions. I enjoy this game, thoroughly; The persistent Prefects only add to the immersion.

Getting a little angry now.Day 7 - I keep trying and trying, but it's those stupid blowfish.Day 12 - Should I beat up the Nerds? Is this even worth it? I've tried over 50 times now...Day 21 - The Nerd Challenge still sits there. It taunts me.Day 35 - All the Nerds are gone. Technically, I can take the place, but Fatty's high score still sits there.Day 48 - The arcade machine is starting to make a grinding noise. I'm sure it's okay.Day 63 - Pretty sure somone robbed the joke shop upstairs. Why? I don't care. I must beat the high score. I must beat the Nerd Challenge.Day 89 - I've ran out of food down here, in the basement of the joke shop. Gone without food for nearly 10 days now. I refuse to go up. I must complete the Nerd Challenge.Day 99 - I think I've been considered missing. Even dead. Still haven't beat the high score.Day 146 - 999 lb. Then a blowfish got me. They must die.Day 234 - People are knocking on the locked door now. I can't let them break my concentration.Day 304 - The arcade machine stopped working completely. I can't open the door. I'm stuck down here. I've been eating rats that come down here. I think I've ran out of rats.Day 4,321 - I got the acrade machine working again. I beat the Nerd Challenge. Apparently there was a nuclear apocalypse while I was out there. Oh, well.10/10 best Rockstar game.

												I remember putting this game into my PS2 way back when thinking it would just be Grand Theft Auto in a school. But boy was I happy that I was wrong. Everything about Bully, whether it be its characters, atmosphere, or even its soundtrack, just gives it way more personality than some Grand Theft Autos. It never feels like a chore to play, with more varied missions that keep it interesting long after you'd usually get bored with a GTA campaign. When I saw it on the Summer Sale, I got without hesitation and started my journey through Bullworth Academy for my 4th time. The only complaint I have with the game is that the towns outside of the school never feel as fleshed out or interesting. But that and minor glitches aside, Bully is a fenominal game. And if you have a controller nearby to use, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fenominal port.

content:
er 31, 2013
												A small town GTA-like game about an increadibly aggressive but at the same time noble boy at the Bullworth Academy. It surely is not a perfect game, but still worth playing in my oppinion, because of its unique scenario and storyline. If you want to try it, pick it up at a sale, it is often available at very low prices.Overall the story was nice, very unrealistic at times, but still nice. It features some very odd humor and a highly stereotypical view at US school environments. The mission design seemed to me to be a lot easier on the player than the GTA 3 and IV series of games (which were frustratingly hard and unforgiving at times). I think of this as a mostly positive thing, but some missions like most of the races just felt a bit too easy. The game has five story chapters including a lot of separate missions and additionally has a bunch of minigames called classes which can be accessed at specific day times or are forced upon you if the school agents catch you while classes are running. Most of these classes were quite OK and revolve around pressing the right buttons when signalled or dragging icons to marked places. One of the classes on the other hand was so hard that I skipped it all along after three retries.The game was first released in 2006 and was ported to PC in 2008, a few months before GTA IV was released. The graphics level more resembles GTA San Andreas than GTA IV and looks quite ugly by 2013 standards. There are also quite a lot of rendering and texture glitches and a 30 frames per second limit in the PC version. The latter can be solved by a modified executable file (check the Steam guides) which works mostly fine but breaks one mission. Even if the PC port was overly hungry for resources (I do not know, but most Rockstar ports are) this didn't affect me much anymore because the game ran very smooth on the highest settings on hardware from 2013.I cannot state much about the keyboard/mouse control scheme, which other commentators stated to be horrific (which would resemble the situation of the GTA 3 and IV series ports) because I played the game with an Xbox 360 wireless controller through the PC adapter. Played with the controller the game's handling didn't feel so bad, but could have been done a bit better at times. The combat, even though there were quite a lot of moves to be acquired throughout the game, most of the times felt quite annoying. The vehicle mechanics like skateboard, bikes and go-carts didn't feel bad at all.

content:
ry 28, 2015
Welcome to Bullworth Academy, an interesting place to say the least. You play as Jimmy Hopkins, a delinquent child on his last chance in an open world. As your progress through the game, you unlock access to more parts of the world, which contains a vast area to explore. This game is a classic, and is just as fun today as it was 10 years ago.Pros:+Visuals have aged very well for a 10 year old game+The gameplay is smooth, with the encounter of a bug being very rare+Very playable, third time playing this game from start to finish and was still enjoyable+Open world full of quirks to explore+Characters fit to their groups seamlessly, making it seem very close to a real school experience+Wide variety of characters with each dialogue fitting in almost naturally +Each environment is carefully designed and makes the setting seem almost realCons:-Main story is generally short, possibly beatable in one long sitting-Sounds sometimes seem out of place, removing a little from the immersion -Limited to a certain playstyle, most choices are made for youOverall this game is a classic, and I highly reccomend it. Well worth full price.9/10
